lesson.title: Sorry we’re late!
lesson.backstory:
Pailin’s host dad Mark has just brought Pailin to her host family’s home for the first time. She will be staying with them during her school year at UCLA, and they’re all welcoming her into their home. Sylvie has just prepared lunch for everyone.

Mark: host dad, lawyer, from the US
Sylvie: host mom, wine distributor, from France
Luke: host brother, 21, also a student at UCLA
Emily: host sister, 13, in high school

transcript.speaker: Mark
transcript.line_text: Guys, we’re home! Sorry we’re late. The traffic was bad.

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Welcome, Pailin! We’re so happy you’re here!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Thank you, it’s so nice to meet you all!

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Sorry the house is a little messy.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Don’t worry! Your home is beautiful.

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Hi Pailin, I’m Luke. I’ll take your suitcase to your room. crashing sounds Oh no! I’m so sorry for dropping your suitcase!

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: That’s okay! It’s just clothes. Hi, are you Emily?

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: Yep, that’s me! Pailin, do you have a boyfriend?

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Emily! Sorry, she’s so rude.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: laughs It’s okay! No, I don’t have a boyfriend.

transcript.speaker: Mark
transcript.line_text: Okay everyone, lunch is ready. Let’s eat.

comprehension_questions.prompt: Why were Mark and Pailin late arriving home?
options: A. Because there was a car accident.
B. Because the traffic was bad.
C. Because they picked up some food.

sections.content_md: In the conversation, Mark apologizes to his family because they arrived late for lunch. Pretend you lost your friend’s phone charger while you were traveling together. How can you apologize to him?
Lesson focus: How to use the word ‘sorry’

lesson.title: I’m an Art History major
lesson.focus:
How to make negative sentences with ‘don’t’ and ‘doesn’t’
Verb Tense: Present Simple Tense
lesson.backstory: Pailin has just moved into her host family’s home. She’s getting to know her host brother, Luke.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Luke, are you a student at UCLA too?

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: Yep! What’s your major?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: I’m an Art History major. How about you?

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: I’m an Engineering major, but I don’t like my classes. I want to change my major.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: You don’t want to be an engineer?

transcript.speaker: Luke
transcript.line_text: No, I don’t. But my dad doesn’t want me to change my major. I want to try Psychology.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: My friend is a Psychology major, but he doesn’t like it very much.

transcript.speaker: Pailin

comprehension_questions.prompt: What does Luke want to change his major to?
options: A. He wants to be an Engineering major.
B. He wants to be an Art History major.
C. He wants to be a Psychology major.

Lesson focus: How to make negative sentences with ‘don’t’ and ‘doesn’t’

lesson.title: I need a big breakfast
lesson.focus: How to use articles (a · an) before a noun
lesson.backstory: Pailin has recently moved into her host family’s home. She’s chatting with her host dad Mark, her host mom Sylvie, and her host sister Emily as they eat breakfast.

transcript.speaker: Mark
transcript.line_text: So, Pailin, what do you usually eat for breakfast in Thailand?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Sometimes I eat a bowl of rice with an omelete, or sometimes I make a sandwich.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: A sandwich for breakfast? What kind?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Usually an egg and bacon sandwich.

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Oh, that sounds good! I usually just have a cup of coffee and an apple in the morning.

transcript.speaker: Mark
transcript.line_text: I need a big breakfast. I always eat a few bowls of cereal. I love bran flakes.

transcript.speaker: Sylvie
transcript.line_text: Bran flakes?? You sound like an old man. (jokingly)

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: What do you eat for breakfast, Emily?

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.line_text: I eat a banana and toast before school. But sometimes I eat an orange, too.

comprehension_questions.prompt: What does Pailin have for breakfast? (select all that apply)
options: B. An egg and bacon sandwich

comprehension_questions.prompt: What does Sylvie have for breakfast? (select all that apply)
options: B. An egg and bacon sandwich

comprehension_questions.prompt: What does Mark have for breakfast? (select all that apply)
options: B. An egg and bacon sandwich

comprehension_questions.prompt: What does Emily have for breakfast? (select all that apply)
options: B. An egg and bacon sandwich

sections.content_md: In the conversation, Pailin and her host family discuss what they usually have for breakfast. What do people in Thailand normally eat for breakfast? Try using the articles 'a' or 'an' in your answer.
Lesson focus: How to use articles (a · an) before a noun

lesson.title: The Hollywood Walk of Fame will be fun!
lesson.focus:
How to talk about the future with ‘will’

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Hey Chloe!

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Hey Pai! I want to go to the Hollywood Walk of Fame today. Do you want to come?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Yeah! But I won’t be free until 1PM.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: That’s okay, I’ll run some errands first.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Okay great, will you take the metro to the Walk of Fame?

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: No, I won’t. My host mom will drop me off. I’ll ask her to pick you up.

transcript.speaker: Pailin

transcript.speaker: Chloe

transcript.speaker: Pailin

lesson.title: See you in the morning
lesson.backstory:
Pailin spent the day hanging out with her friend Chloe at the Hollywood Walk of Fame. It’s getting late, and tomorrow is their first day of school at UCLA, so they should be getting home soon.

It’s Pailin’s first day of school at UCLA! She’s sitting in a large lecture hall for her first class of the day, East Asian Art. Her professor walks in and begins speaking to the class.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: What time is it?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: It’s almost 10.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Wow, it’s so late! I should sleep soon.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Me too. We have a big day tomorrow.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: I know! I’m so nervous for the first day of school.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Don’t be nervous! It’ll be fun.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: laughs You’re right. What time will you wake up tomorrow morning?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Probably around 8. How about you?

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Same. Let’s get breakfast together.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Okay, sounds good. See you in the morning.

transcript.speaker: Chloe
transcript.line_text: Bye, have a good night. See you.

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Good night!

transcript.speaker: Professor Adams
transcript.line_text: Is everyone here? Okay, let’s get started! I’m Professor Adams, and this class is East Asian Art. You will learn about famous East Asian artists and their artworks. You’ll have two exams: the midterm and the final. We will meet every Monday and Wednesday from 10:30 to 11:30. My office hours are from 5–8PM on Mondays and Wednesdays, and my TA’s office hours are from 6–9PM every weekday. Her office is next to my office. Does anyone have any questions?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Professor, will we have homework assignments?

transcript.speaker: Professor Adams
transcript.line_text: No, this course doesn’t have any homework. But I will give you reading assignments every class. Please read the articles at home, and we will discuss them in class. Any other questions?

transcript.speaker: Pailin
transcript.line_text: Professor, will your lectures be online?

transcript.speaker: Professor Adams
transcript.line_text: Ah, yes. Each class is recorded, so you can watch them if you miss a class. But I recommend coming to class to join in on the discussions. Any more questions? No? Okay, well I think everyone will enjoy this class very much! Okay, let’s begin with Hokusai.
